entry.title: Naughy Dog announces new IP Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet
entry.summary:
As the final reveal of the night for The Game Awards 2024, developer Naughty Dog revealed its next game to be Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet, and is currently in development for PlayStation. According to studio head Neil Druckmann, the studio's new IP has been in development since 2020.
In the roughly four-and-a-half-minute trailer, the main character Jordan, played by Tati Gabrielle (also Nora in The Last of Us show), appears to be a bounty hunter lying low in deep space. According to the announcement post for Intergalactic on Naughty Dog's website, Jordan is stranded on Sempiria, a planet whose communication with the outside universe went dark hundreds of years ago. It's up to Jordan to use her skills and wits to be the first person in over 600 years to leave the planet's orbit.
The teaser looks solid enough, though obviously I have many questions. After all, Naughty Dog is known for its ability to craft incredible stories, so that's what I'm interested in learning more about. However, The Game Awards creator and host Geoff Keighley revealed after the trailer that legendary composers Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross will be scoring Intergalactic which has me pumped.
These types of reveals typically intend to drum up interest in preparation for bigger reveals later down the line, and in this case, it has served that purpose. Show me more, Naughty Dog!

entry.title: Borderlands 4 gets maiden trailer with more guns to ‘break free’
entry.summary:
Borderlands 4 showcased a new trailer at The Game Awards 2024, and there are plenty of reasons for the fans to be excited.
Of course, a lot of important information is yet to be revealed, including the final release date. But there were some important moments in the trailer, including what could be a new movement mechanic. Fans can wishlist the game as of writing, and it could be the start of a new chapter altogether for the franchise.
Borderlands 4 could be a direct sequel to Borderlands 3
For all things better and worse, Borderlands 3 has largely been a mixed affair for the fans. With Borderlands 4, Gearbox has chosen to make the most ambitious project of all time. The official first-look title might not have given us a launch date, but it looks like the good old Pandora that we know.
Players are likely going to have the option to choose between different characters, just like in Borderlands 3. There was a specific scene in the trailer that highlighted the presence of guns of different rarities, which has always been a strong point of the franchise.
Outside that, fans will have to wait till there's an official release date. The game is going to be available for PC and consoles, and it appears (based on now) that old-gen will not be getting the new game. We also know that the release will happen in 2025, and an exact date is likely going to be announced soon by Gearbox.

Gran Saga's global launch, which happened a couple of weeks ago, has introduced the new gacha to mobiles and PC.
It's a free-to-play title that can be played on your handheld, or you could choose to download it via PC. Like every good gacha, there's a tier list of all the characters currently available inside the game. This tier list will help you to sort out your early team, and invest the resources efficiently.
Gran Saga tier list
I have kept three tiers to classify the characters. In Gran Saga, you can potentially use any character currently available to build your team.
S-tier: Strong characters who should be future-proof for the power curve.
A-tier: Decent characters who can be as good as S-tier in certain situations.
B-tier: Good characters who will need a lot of time and investment to reach the late-game stages.
In Gran Saga, characters also have their own elemental type, and it's important to make a squad well-balanced in general to cover the strengths and weaknesses.

entry.title: The Witcher 4 premiers at The Game Awards 2024 with a familiar face

The Game Awards 2024 opened with the first world premiere of The Witcher 4, and it will mark the return of a familiar face in a new avatar.
The new project has already been in work since CD Projekt Red announced it previously, but we now have more details about what to expect. The render, which wasn't gameplay footage in a direct sense, gave the audience a glimpse at some of the potential dangers that Ciri will be facing. The opening footage had her facing a fierce monster to save a village girl from being slaughtered.
It's the first glimpse of the lore that's going to be present in the upcoming project. So far, Ciri remains the only familiar face on the reveal, but it's safe to expect for known faces from The Witcher universe. Incidentally, there was a hint towards the end of the trailer, which could be a proof of Geralt playing some sort of a role. For more, fans will have to wait, and a release date is yet to be announced.
It will be interesting to find out more details about the story and if it will be a direct continuation of the events that took place in The Witcher 3.

As part of The Game Awards 2024, Bandai Namco and FromSoftware have announced a new Standalone entry in the Elden Ring series, Elden Ring: Nightreign. It's set to arrive in 2025.
It will look familiar to anyone who played the original game, but is being described as a "standalone co-op action survival game." Not every sea creature is going to be easy to add to your Bestiary in Fisch, the fishing simulator on Roblox. Where to find Helicoprion in Fisch
The Helicoprion shark can only be found at the Ancient Isle, far east. This island is full of prehistoric fish, including other famous sea creatures like the Mosasaurus and the Megalodon.

entry.title: How to catch the Whisker Bill in Fisch
entry.summary:
The Roblox fishing simulator, Fisch, features common cods you can find just about anywhere, and mythical sea creatures that take tenacity and patience to find. In fact, there’s a fish so rare it was thought to be extinct: The Whisker Bill. Here's how you can find and catch it.
Where to find the Whisker Bill in Fisch
The Whisker Bill can only be found on the island of Moosewood, either at the docks or at the back of the island. The best spot to find it is at the small island you can reach by boat behind Moosewood itself. It has a few trees and a cliff. You can easily hop on any boat and make your way over to begin fishing in the area. You can see it directly from the docks on the back of the island. I’d recommend standing on the corner of the island facing the main part of Moosewood as this area has the highest spawn rate for the Whisker Bill.
Screenshot by Destructoid
How to get the Whisker Bill in Fisch
You’ll want a Truffle Worm to lure the Whisker Bill in, which you can find inside Coral Geodes, Volcanic Geodes, or Treasure Chests. Coral Geodes only cost 600 C$ from the shop, so I’d recommend these. If you complete 50 or more Angler quests, you’ll also get a Truffle Worm for your trouble.
Once you’ve got the bait and are at the right spot, cast your lure into the water. The Whisker Bill doesn’t have any preference for time of day, season, or weather, but it is a Mythical-class rarity fish, so it won't be easy to find. When you’ve got one on your lure, a pink exclamation point will pop up, indicating that you’re luring a Mythical fish.
The Whisker Bill moves around the fishing bar a lot, and you’ll take a 20% progress speed decrease when trying to catch it. This won’t be too noticeable unless you have a very fast rod, but you can still tell.
Whether you’re looking to complete your Bestiary or just want to show off to your friends, the Whisker Bill is a great fish and gives you a nice 150 XP when you catch it.

entry.title: Does Marvel Rivals have cross-progression? Explained
entry.summary:
When it comes to huge multiplayer releases like Marvel Rivals, the question is whether the game is cross-play or cross-platform. In many cases, it does, but in instances like this, the answer will vary.
Does Marvel Rivals have cross-progression?
Unfortunately, Marvel Rivals does not have or support cross-progression. If you were hoping to play on PC and switch over to consoles like Xbox or PS5, you wouldn’t be able to carry progression over, including skins and unlocks.
This does mean that all purchases will have to be made again if you play between platforms. All earned currencies like Units, Lattice, and Chrono Tokens will have to be earned or purchased again too.
Does Marvel Rivals have crossplay?
Luckily, if you want to at least play with friends on other matchmaking pools, you can do that. There are some restrictions, though.
If you have a group that wants to play together, then Quick Play, Conquest, Custom Games, and Practice modes will be the only things you can play. Ranked and Competitive modes will be restricted.
Screenshot by Destructoid
What to do if you have multiple platforms to play on
If you want to partake in activities like ranked, especially with friends, you will have to all coordinate playing on the same matchmaking realm.
For example, PC players can only play with PC, and console players can only play between Xbox and PlayStation. Due to mechanics like aim assist on consoles and PC players being able to turn quicker, these two matchmaking pools have to be separate.
The last hurdle in matching together on the same Competitive matchmaking pool is that you need to ensure you’re level 10 to play in these playlists. Otherwise, you’ll only have Quickplay.
And if quickplay is the case, you’re better off sticking to your primary platform for the foreseeable future so you won’t miss out on account and Battle Pass progression.

entry.title: Total War: Warhammer’s Rich Aldridge on roleplaying, iteration, and lessons from nearly a decade on strategy’s most ambitious series
entry.summary: In more ways than one, today’s Total War: Warhammer 3 expansion marks a milestone for game director Rich Aldridge and his team at Creative Assembly. Omens Of Destruction’s three headline legendary lords each bring new campaigns and units for their respective factions, but it’s the fourth lord - a Khorne champion free to all players - that I imagine Aldridge will end up remembering the most fondly. When Total War: Warhammer released back in 2016, it shipped with eight legendary lords - famous characters from Games Workshop’s fantasy setting that here act as faction leaders. The number grew steadily and, in terms of announcement order at least, today’s addition of Arbaal The Undefeated marks the series’ 100th. That's a hundred campaigns, a hundred joint efforts of game design, animation, art, writing and voice work. Aldridge has never been shy about the team’s ambition for the series to eventually offer up each unit from every Fantasy Battle 6th edition army book ("The goal is to do everything, right?"). But ambition is one thing, and considering the fraught conditions at Creative Assembly and parent company Sega over the past few years, it’s not just the addition of the 100th lord that feels like something to celebrate. It’s taken time, effort, and a siesmic shift in update frequency, but Total War: Warhammer III is in the best place it's ever been. Read more

entry.title: Naiad review: still waters run deep they say, but then these waters aren't still
entry.summary:
Pity the "relaxing" games which set out to blanket their players in a wholesome fog. These minimalist or slight experiences set their stall against the mainstream philosophy of video game design focused on action, rules, clear progression, and often violence. So it is with Naiad, a sometimes pleasant swim down a river in which you sing to make flowers grow and discover poems by interacting with birds, bees, butterflies and other fauna.
Yet here's the cause of my pity. All those other games, with their decisive action, systemic consequence, and neck-snapping: I was playing those to relax, too. Why else would I have snapped all those necks? Being shorn of base pleasures does not make Naiad a restorative oasis amid a desert of stressful video games, and it doesn't make it more relaxing than its peers. In fact, it makes for an experience that left me restless, even a little anxious, when it made me feel anything at all.

entry.title: Beautiful, brainy space RTS Nebulous: Fleet Command is getting carriers and fightercraft

I feel guilty about repeatedly comparing Nebulous: Fleet Command to Homeworld, inasmuch as it's an appalling bait-and-switch. It's like offering somebody a cake that is actually a cunningly painted hunk of torpedo fuselage. It's like offering to shake hands while wearing one of those comedy hand buzzers - except that the hand buzzer is an intricate simulation of zero-G physics, missile behaviours and comms jamming, featuring spacecraft with proper internal layouts that require you to think hard about attitude control if you don't want, say, your engines to become Swiss cheese about 90 seconds before you need to retreat from combat.
Being a "true" 3D real-time space strategy game, Nebulous looks and sounds a lot like Homeworld on the surface, but it's nothing like as straightforward. It is systems within systems. It is a game in which you can, theoretically, plot the path of a single guided munition through an asteroid field, so as to catch an enemy cruiser in the back. entry.title: Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 review: a wonky career mode gives meaning to the formless flight sim
entry.summary: London Gatwick Airport is a rare shade of brown, known to neither science nor art. A brown that doesn’t appear on the light spectrum. No easel contains it. It is a dusty brown, a damp brown, a hot and earthy brown that hums with the stinging malodour of disturbed ancient moss where once old forests stood. Descending into Gatwick’s cloying brown from 33,000 feet is like flying under and up Gandalf’s wretched cloak and landing in one of the several horrible little magic pouches he keeps by his balls. Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 captures Gatwick’s brown perfectly. Next to the stupefying natural beauty of Yosemite, the imposing imperial skyscrapers of the Manhattan skyline and the surging majesty of the Alpine peaks, this local rot-tinged patch of West Sussex is the most impressively realistic depiction of a place I have seen in a game. entry.title: I have rarely hated a bad guy as much as I hate Voss in Indiana Jones And The Great Circle
entry.summary: It's not just because he's a Nazi. It's because he's a smartass Nazi. As the main antagonist in Indiana Jones And The Great Circle, Emmerich Voss vacates the archetypal armchair usually reserved for secondary fascist goons, so that he can goosestep straight into the big boy seat himself. He smiles with all the sleaze of right-hand-man Major Toht, the grubby gestapo who gets that right hand burned in Raiders of the Lost Ark. Yet he also engages in the pseudo-intellectual trash talk of the main archaeological rivals to Jones, like Rene Belloq or Walter Donovan. He is a hideous grab bag of all the things that make an instantly detestable villain in the series. But there's something else. Voss is so immediately and gutturally hateable because he resembles a type of racist encountered not in the 1930s, but one you've probably met today: the asshole you meet on the internet. entry.title: It’s worth downloading the demo for uncanny horror Eclipsium just to stare at your hands
entry.summary: The only sound that greets you upon booting up Eclipsium is a loudly throbbing heart. As one must when encountering horror media, the game and I immediately enter a spiritual staring contest, each of us knowing the real game here was it trying to freak me out. "It’s fine", I decided. "It’s just a heart! I’ve got a heart. It’s actually very useful. Nothing to be scared of". Thing is, Eclipsium’s menu heart is actually massive and sits, like The Eye Of Sauron, atop a giant obelisk. “Ah. That’s definitely a horror thing, that” I was forced to admit. "If my heart was on a giant obelisk, I’d be proper shaken up, I reckon." So starts Eclipsium’s very first bit of aggressive disorientation, and it basically just escalates from there. I obviously can’t describe the vibes without slightly spoiling the vibes, so do pop over to Steam for a demo if you’re curious and, oh, there’s a potted plant, the sound of its rustling mixed in such a way that it sort of sounds like it’s shrieking at me. Both (the best Final Fantasy game) Final Fantasy 8’s Squall and The Witcher 3’s Geralt simply cannot get enough of leaving their friends and the entire world in mortal peril while they sneak in a quick round of cards, and I love them for it. Way back when the Wild Hunt released, there was a special edition kicking about that gave you a few decks for Gwent - the fleshed-out, playable card distraction that ended up being responsible for some of the game’s best moments. entry.title: Indiana Jones And The Great Circle review: a grand adventure that keeps faith with the movies
entry.summary:
Every fascist in this game has a cold. The Hitlerites and blackshirts of Indiana Jones And The Great Circle sneeze and cough as they patrol the dig sites of Gizeh, or the marble corridors of the Vatican. Although this is the Machine Games' clever way of letting you know where your enemies are at all times, it is also mildly funny, as if all the Nazis have been secretly kissing each other, spreading the same rhinovirus from Italy to Egypt to Nepal and beyond. More than that, it's a stubborn reminder that, despite the many hours of perfectly motion-captured cinematics that accompany all this, you are still playing a video game. A snotty tissue that separates the Indy of taut two-hour cinema and the Indy of a sweeping first-person punch 'em up that will take days to complete. All this is to say, you will notice the difference. But that might not matter; they're both still Indiana Jones.

entry.title: The Thing: Remastered review: a fantastic remaster of a game best observed from a distance
entry.summary: Nightdive, you done good. The Thing: Remastered is an ultra-sharp and commendably playable update to a game that history will remember as ‘actually a pretty good pick at Choices when you really just popped in to get some Revels but got embarrassed when the till staffer said “is that everything?” in a tone that could have been neutral but equally could have been a damning indictment of your character’. I’m being slightly facetious here, of course. History actually remembers Computer Artworks’s 2002 shooty horror game for how incredibly ambitious and conceptually inventive its proto-sus social squad system was. In homage to the body-snatching alien paranoia of Carpenter’s 1982 horror classic, The Thing tasks you with not just assembling and directing a squad, but keeping them from breaking down or turning on you - in fear you might be hosting the titular molecular stowaway. One of my favourite anime shows is Sakura Quest. It's the story of an unemployed lady from Tokyo who accidentally gets herself appointed "Queen" of a struggling backwater village by the regional tourist board. But I'll let lesser reporters tell you about that stuff. I'm here to report that Capcom have made the big bonk feel good again. They’ve heard player feedback on the missing weapon oomph caused by the lack of hitstop in the Monster Hunter Wilds beta, and they’re bringing back the bonk. Existuje vícero českých filmů, které surfují na oblíbené vlně "zakažte exekutory, zrušte dluhy, je to nelidské!" (například Tancuj Matyldo). After Party takovým filmem není. Exekutoři se v něm chovají korektně a slušně a vinu na situaci celé rodiny nese naprosto jednoznačně otec, který neopatrně investoval, i když nevíme jak.
